39447503.review: This game is possibly my favorite myst-like. The puzzles throughout build repeatedly on the same concepts and ideas in a way that feels like that riven style of satisfaction, with perhaps a little less of the moonlogic. A few specific points the way ahead is slightly unclear, but that's more a problem of the genre in general and this game does a great job with that tough-but-intuitive ideas. The game gets a tad too narrative focused towards the end, making the conclusion feel a bit weakened. Strangely however, that comes right after one of my favorite puzzles in games in a long time so take that as you will. While the game lacks a climactic puzzle finale, it certainly holds strong enough throughout to be one of the best puzzle games around.

Highly recommended.

39361029.review:
A wonderful and intriguing adventure.
Feels like a mix between 'The Room' and 'Obduction', which is very appreciated.

[b]Pros[/b]:
[list]
[*] Interesting storyline
[*] Beautiful locations and landscape
[*] Puzzles are nicely crafted, with a raising level of difficulty
[*] Interesting mechanics, such as 'Notes and Drawings'
[/list]

[b]Notes[/b]:
[list]
[*] The endings are a bit of a let down. Leaves lot to the immagination
[*] The performance can be a bit taxing on higher resolutions and settings
[*] Some puzzles, such as [spoiler] the alchemy labs ones, where you have to pick ingrendients for a special formula, [/spoiler] can be particularly hard, due the not immediate and hidden clues 

Overally, if you are into the genre (first person puzzles with exploration, similar to Obduction), this is a game you should not miss.

39348101.review: Только закончил прохождение. Впечатления яркие и приятные. Я не постоянный игрок в квесты и если бы не Youtube игру не прошел. Такое впечатление, что подсказок было больше, но 80% из них убрали. Да, задачи разнообразные, и некоторые решал с первого взгляда. Но были такие, решение в которых совсем не очевидно. Чего не хватает игре, так это знакомства с головоломками. Если бы вместе с игрой было руководство, пускай электронное. Конечно не с пошаговыми инструкциями, но хотя бы с примерами решений, что бы подсказать, что куда вставить. В целом, зря я наверное высказываю недовольство. Как никак был бы моложе, да не работал, наверняка застрял бы в игре с удовольствием. А еще, уже давно я столько не рисовал, не записывал и не считал. Игра отличная, через годик повторю прохождение.

39342067.review:
I'm really happy I found this gem. I was filled with nostalgia, with a mood very reminiscent from Riven (Myst 2), except with a modern engine and graphics. It was awesome.

I think the difficulty was just right. We completed it in about 12 hours, with no major headscratchers. Aficionados may find it too easy, especially with the highlight feature that prevents you from missing details in the environment. But I thought that was a welcomed change from the genre, as it would let you focus on logical puzzle solving instead of pixel hunting.

I particularily appreciated the puzzle design, which brought a lot of "aha!" moments with clever device usages. I also liked how some puzzles can be very easily solved if you have the right mathematical knowledge at hand (like aligning the globes by echeloning an incidence matrix...)

39340629.review: I never really was an adventure or puzzle solving game fan, but Quern just showed me how cool it can be! The combination of the mystical, consistent story line and world physics with the superior, well-thought user control/interface makes this game outstanding! Enjoyed it a lot wthether high or sober!

39326137.review: 你成功地进入了机关室，你肯定已经完成了我先前的挑战。这可能代表你是个能满足我期望的天才并有资格获得我即将給予你的知识。或者你也可能是个傻瓜，因为Quern能够给予你无止境的时间来想出我谜题的答案。

39307659.review:
Замечатленое приключение! Как по мне, то немного хуже The Withness из-за слишком серой палитры, меньшей продолжитлеьности и линейности. Но вот разнообразие и сложность головоломок явно лучше чем в игре с лабиринтами.

39159266.review: Отличное развлечение на несколько вечеров для тех, кому нравятся головоломки в стиле Myst'а. Разработчики явно им вдохновлялись. Был настроен скептически, но игра превзошла мои ожидания. Наличие хорошей видеокарты весьма желательно. Моя средненькая высокие настройки не потянула.

39151561.review: A truly fantastic Myst-style game.  It was a challenging game - an I needed help a few times - but almost all the puzzels were fair.  There was only one time when I thought the solution was unfair.

39138194.review:
A wonderful game. The puzzles are logical and I never got completely stuck at any point in the game, and never felt frustrated either. There are many "A-ha" moments when things just click and make sense, which is very rewarding. 

I grew up with the Myst series, and now I was able to play this game with my kids and watch their excitement at solving puzzles and discovering the well built world. If you enjoyed the Myst series, don't pass this one up.

39134708.review: An awesome puzzle game with a great, MYST-like vibe. So much content too, definitely worth the buy.

39125557.review:
Although this game has its frustrating moments, it is a thousand times better than Myst or The Witness.

Pros:
Most of the puzzles will peak your curiosity, then you'll stumble upon another object that gives you that "A-ha!" moment, you'll go back to that puzzle you couldn't figure out earlier, you'll solve it, and you'll feel like a f*cking genius.
The graphics are top notch and laid out very nicely.
Some of the stuff in the game is fun to just screw around with even if you can't solve it right away.

39117730.review: Absolutely brilliant.  The puzzles are challenging but ultimately do-able. 39111004.review:
First a caveat: If you have an AMD R9 graphics card, you may experience very poor performance. Despite my system well exceeding the recommended requirements for 1080p, I was forced to play in 720p as a result of this issue. Bummer, but not a deal-breaker.

If you are a fan of Myst or puzzle games in general, you should play this game. The puzzles, story, graphics, music, environment are all wonderful. There is a clear Myst influence, but Quern easily lives up to or exceeds the Myst legacy. The world is incredibly compact, and there is real delight in discovering whole new areas in places you thought were mostly explored as you solve puzzles. Also, a special mention for the music, which I loved listening to no matter how long I spent on a puzzle. I got stuck a few times, but never had to resort to spoilers, so I found the challenge level to be very satisfying.

Go play it!!

39110705.review:
Wonderfully immersive world. Can really get stuck into this. If you like mystery, magic and adventure you're probably bound to enjoy this game just for the story it seems to thus far tell. 

FPS movement done really well, sound design is great, music is a bit on the repetitive side but when music is a complaint you know the game is good. Puzzles really have annoyed the quern out of me, and when you finally solve them it feels awesome. Difficult but rewarding. 

Graphics are real nice and has controller support. Haven't played yet with controller but diving in now; if there's anything to complain about I'll post it here. 

Give it a shot, it's worth the cash and if you don't like it refund it. I don't think you'll want to.

39095861.review:
I would love another Myst-like game, but unfortunately Quern is marred by stubbornly bad technological decisions so I couldn't even bother to play it. It has such bad performance even the starting menu caused my fans to run hot just idling.

After trying to get it to work at an acceptable level for an hour over a few days so it doesnt cook my hardware, I crawled the discussion boards for ways to improve the performance outside of the very limited graphic options in game but didn't find anything of value. It's nearly unplayable in terms of minimum requirements and I can't reccommend it to anyone as it looks and plays worse than 5 to 15 year old games that have a good design phillosophy. 

Quern is anything but modern, it is made in Unity5, but I don't believe it's Unity's fault the game runs so badly. Quern's unreasonably taxing on any hardware is due to how the devs built the game like 2 ton weights dropped on your GPU and RAM and if your PC can handle the strain the devs consider it 'optimized' which is far from it.. The hardware specifications are very misleading even when hitting the recommended settings, and honestly if the game was made properly it wouldn't need anywhere near them. Indie graphics are one thing but this sort of sub-par performance is another. 

Watching the trailer you would expect to be able to run it no problem at at least a solid 30fps when you have played more visually impressive games like I have, but you would be wrong. The game is about 15 hours from the developer's mouth, but they decided to load nearly everything at once on the island into the engine making the game entirely bruteforcing your hardware and it has zero smart use of optimization methods. There's only maybe a maximum of 2 splits in loading Quern. Good luck If you dont have over 8+GB of RAM as it loads everything on the island with no game loading afterwords. The per-pixel realtime rendering (that you cant turn off) causes GPUs far too much work that tanks fps unless you play in tiny fuzzy resolutions because the developer have chosen not to use any modern technique like culling.

Performance wise is anything but good... when brought up repeatedly, the only thing the developer keeps saying is play it on the lowest resolution at 600x800, avoiding the elephant in the room that the game isnt optimized in the slightest capacity and they actively chose a method that is antithetical to optimization. It has been a year since release... and the optimization patches months apart only make bandaid changes. The dev gave excuses or goes silent when pressed about atrociously bad optimization when compared to other modern or older games. When looking around for reviews, Quern even has big problems and can drop fps to 10-20fps on the recommended specs (again no use of culling, as it tries to offload everything to the GPU all at once)

There is absolutely no justification to making a game almost entirely bruteforced. It's been the standard for decades, even in the case of big taxing games, to split loading rooms, cutscenes and swap assets out for lower quality ones so this sort of thing doesnt happen. Quern needs to be entirely reworked for a smarter workload to allow seamless loading between much smaller chunks with portals and or allow you to turn off the per-pixel based realtime lighting for baked lighting or pre-rendered scenes, but as is the only video options they allow you to tweak to get better fps turn the game into a gray pixelated mess or a fuzzy tiny window. Instead the devs pursued getting 4k support into the game and leaving lower to middle end hardware out to dry.

Nothing in Quern justifies the excessive demand on the hardware, it's just held down due to bad development decisions and until the developer treats these issues with more serious care than just relying on Unity patches I'm giving it a thumbs down. Quern deserves better than this and it's the team's responsibility to deliver on some quality assurance.

39080790.review:
It's rare for me to leave feedback even months after buying games.

This puzzle-based world is as intriguing as it is beautiful. Even with all the settings on low on my laptop. The plot is gripping and was enough to drive me through the game at a rather faster pace than I normally give to puzzle games.

I have only two problems with this game. One I feel I say about every puzzle game. You can get stuck for ages not knowing what to do not because there's a tough puzzle but because there are "for later" interactable items which do nothing and the next thing you need to do doesn't look like it is interactable. This was marginally well done in this game in that you can bind a key to highlight interactable items and machines.

The second problem broke immersion for me only once. You are not allowed to swim or climb areas that look very simple to swim or climb. Half of the early puzzles could be skipped if the player knew how to vault a small rock.

Overall a very good game with the typical banes of its genre. I do not begrudge it these.

To put it simply: this game is puzzle adventure done right. 

I've been searching for a worthy Myst successor for many years but I've never found a game that could quite measure up to the legendary status that is the Myst/Riven series... until now. This is the game that Obduction wanted to be.

39018145.review:
As many have said, in recent years, this is the closest I got to feeling like I was playing one of the earlier Myst games again. The puzzles were usually pretty good, although there were a few where you know what you're supposed to do but you kind of have to math it out... Which I tend not to like doing. And puzzle fatigue sets in at some point as you spend 30 minutes getting the logic just right on a couple of mathy puzzles...

Maybe the only real complaint I'd have is that, while the story was interesting, there was maybe not quite enough of it. And for a setting that is a multi-world universe, it is kind of sad to not get to explore more than one world. I hope this gets a world-travelling sequel.

All in all, one of the good examples of puzzle and exploration games, with a very nice and soothing atmosphere. Recommended.

38965007.review:
This is my first negative review on Steam.  I always give a game a chance.  I find things to appreciate because I recognize I'm toying with someone's hard work and creativity.  That said, here's my review:

The premise and story are contrived, and the puzzles and visuals are uninspired.  In short, the game is lame.

Note:  I didn't play the game all the way through because after having made significant progress with little effort, the game suddenly lost all direction.  It was like, is there even another puzzle for me to solve?  What, where?  More to the point, why do I care?  The game gives no sense of urgency to the player for making further progress, and then it refuses to give any indication of what to do next.  That's not the kind of "mystery" you want to design into a game like this.  I didn't care enough to look up a walkthrough online, I just stopped playing and never looked back.

Pros:
-Self-updating map screen
-Awesome "Journal" feature that allows you to take pictures (as "sketches" on each page), to which you can add a brief note.  I used it extensively as I went, as if it really was my own journal, and I have to say it was the most fun I had while playing.  Yes, that's as sad as it sounds.  The document I created by myself was the best part of the game.  What does that tell you?
-The voice acting isn't terrible.

Cons:
-Lazy design work.  For example, every tree on the island is a pine, and it's the exact same model for each.  The size doesn't even vary.

I give this game a thumbs down not because anything stood out as extremely bad, but because nothing stood out at all.  If it had been a bold but failed experiment, I could at least have appreciated the attempt at innovation.  You get a lot of indie games like that.  They're trying hard, but it just doesn't work.  Quern is not even trying.  The creators seem to have picked up the formula for how to construct a puzzle game from the greats that pioneered the genre, and then put their own project together in color-by-number fashion.  Mechanically, they built it competently enough.  But no love went into the game.  Therefore, I consider my time and money wasted.

4/10

38958801.review: 这个是我玩过的解谜游戏里面最棒的，没有之一，但是真的有点难，脑子不行慎入。

38955704.review:
I bought this game after reading that it was like Myst, but even better. I have to say that I 100% agree with that statement.

Quern puts you on this magical island, where you follow the foodsteps of professor Maythorn. To find out why you are there you need to solve countless amazing puzzles.
The puzzles are at just the right level of challenging where most of them you won't solve right away, but you won't be stuck for hours without and end in sight.
The art in the game is amazing. Some models are a bit low on the polygon side, but it does not take away much from the beauty of the game. The lighting is especially well done in this game, it sets a great mood, and really lets the world shine.

The only minor complaints I have about this game is that controller support is a bit limited, the main menu is not browsable with a controller and some of the puzzles are hard to do with one. I kept switching between keyboard & mouse and controller.
The load time is also quite long, but that is only there when you start the game.

It took me about 15 hours of game time to finish the game, and during that time it kept unfolding and surprising me.

The only big complaint I have now is, that it's over, and I want more. I suppose that's just what Quern does to people. :)

38950905.review:
As a fan of Myst, I dowloaded it and was not disappointed.  Quern is an excellent game.  Well planned out, engaging, with an interesting storyline.

There were some very fascinating puzzles, like the Alchemy, but there were also some exceedingly frustrating ones.  For much of the game I had to proceed with a walkthrough by my side to tell me the object of the puzzle - so I could then figure out the solution for myself.  There were only 2 that I had to look up the solution because they were so cryptic I couldn't work them out.  Sometimes it was not clear what exactly you had accomplished, opening one of a dozen locked doors.  My advice is to have a walkthrough on hand just to point you in the right direction and save you hours of aimless wandering.  There is one task in particular that seems completely random to me, and I would never have finished the game otherwise.

Quern is big and wonderful, and there are things you will encounter that you won't understand until later, which is part of the fun. :)

38950004.review: Super jeu vraiment bien fais j'ai adoré dommage qu'il exsiste pas ce genre de jeu en coop !! sinon je le recommande vivement ,il est tres beau et tres agréable a jouer !!! vivement que des dev se decident a nous sortir ce genre de jeux en coop les couples passerons leur soirées devant l'ecran ^^

38795980.review: Un excellent descendant de Myst qui réalise l'exploit de ne pas commettre d'incohérence majeure. 38793943.review:

38775618.review:
15h playtime (w/o walkthrough), compared to games like Myst, ASA/Catyph, and Obduction:
Game is 3D with free, FPS-like movement.
Feels like 1 single world of a Myst game.

+ no dead-ends, no time-pressure
+ ingame feature to record/capture screen with notes (very handy)
+ inventory feature to inspect items further
+ scientific, nice, calm world to explore
+ (almost) all writings are read to you
+ save-game-feature (no checkpoints, but autosave)

- minor graphic issues/improvements (e.g. trees)
- no steam cloud saves
- some crashes (sometimes, but with autosaves not much of a problem, just inconvenient loading times)
- high system requirements for maximum graphics quality

38673089.review:
The presentation could use a *lot* of work. A dude kidnaps you and expects you to "enjoy his wonders". How about no? That, along with a lot of the more "gamey" aspects turned me off of the entire ordeal. I don't want a popup saying I've discoved a new place, I want to discover a new place. I don't want to use this one torch for everything, I want to steal on off of the wall.

I can't help but compare it to other puzzle games, like Myst, The Witness, and The Talos Principle. Each of those was able to sidestep the problems that were *immediately* apparent in this game.

I didn't play for long, so there could be an incredible ending, or even an incredible middle, but the beginning didn't inspire me to play further.

38642414.review: Highly recommended.  If you're like me, you played Myst as a kid and never thought that experience would come around again.  It did.  Quern is a masterpiece.  Inventive, multi-solution puzzles and a well-written story drive the game.  The puzzles are interesting and satisfying without ever becoming frustrating. 38636356.review:
This is my very first review on steam. Even though I have a few dozens of games in my library, i played every other game with certain expectations and it was matched (for the most part). Quern on the other hand blew all those expectations out the window. As an induvidual game developer and a real enthusiast of this genre of games, I have tried my hand at it only to be met with varying results of success. Quern on the other hand feels almost like a AAA puzzler created by an indie studio. 

There are a few minor flaws but as a huge fan of the Myst series, this is the sequel we should have gotten to Riven. Myst 3: Exile is a competantly made game but really easy at times. With Quern, i found the right balance of figuring out puzzles really quickly and being stumped at certain points in time unable to progress. The comparison to Riven is inevitable as the whole world of Quern is one entity and compeonents from different parts of the world solve puzzles in another. This is a solid effort from an indie studio and it never feels like it. This game was the best $5 i have ever spent on steam since the Talos principle (which is also an awesome puzzle game..with it's own game mechanics). Immensely recommended for all fans of puzzle games and especially fans of the Myst series!

I would love to play a sequel to this someday! It's that good.

38621235.review: Gave me that Myst-like experience I had wanted for a long time.

38615686.review:
Quern is a good game, I did not get any bugs, the graphics are nice-looking, it runs relatively well and offers a good playtime. So why a negative review? Because I did not enjoy it. I bought the game thinking to play another clone of Myst, but in fact it absolutely is not. I guess I was disappointed. The game is in fact a clone of The room on an island. It is awfully linear (you can only solve one puzzle after the other) and the numerous puzzles are mostly way too simple. Still some puzzles are interesting like the laser, sound and alchemy puzzles, but other than that, there is not much brainstorming to do, or any feelings of achievement to have. Put that object here, push those few buttons, and hop, puzzle solved!… Mostly I was bored... Until the end I was still hoping for an increasing difficulty, but gosh I was disappointed… I was just glad it was over…

The story is ok I guess, but not strong enough and too predictable to make the game more interesting.

If there is a sequel, I wish it will be less linear, that there will be more exploration and less puzzles but with a higher complexity... I suppose I can wish. There are not so many puzzle games out there…

In all it is a good game, but I would recommend it for young players or players that are new to puzzle games.

38596284.review:
Quern - Undying Thoughts is excellent.  If you were a fan of (the inevitable comparisons) Myst and Riven, you will absolutely enjoy your time here.  I sat down and completed the game in 1 session (I got no sleep last night).  There was only one puzzle that I did not enjoy, and thats because I don't understand it.  Even after watching a walkthrough for that puzzle (after beating my head against the desk for a good hour trying to brute force it) and listening to the person give their logic for the solution, then inputing that solution, I still dont understand it (LOL!).  I simply could not figure out how to interpret the diagrams.  It was around 4 am when I got to this section, so that may have everything to do with it, but it sticks out to me.  Every other puzzle was fantastic.

Pros
-Awesome world design and graphics
-Great puzzles
-Good, if not limited, music
-A+ Voice acting. 
-Compelling story
-Difficulty is just right

Cons
-Frame drops and reduced performance during the 3rd quarter of the game (due to "everything" being opened up?).

Absolutely, without question, would recommend this game.

38584408.review:
tldr: get a walkthrough.

This is Riven-style puzzle design: make exploring and backtracking mandatory, and throw in a bunch of puzzles that most people probably won't be able to get. Except you have an inventory and it's up to you to ensure you have the right stuff on hand at all times.

For instance, you get two torches, one orange and one blue. You can place each of them in any number of places. You will need them, but you can easily set them down and forget where you put them, and then you pretty much have to start over. Except sometimes you need to leave them somewhere and walk away for a bit.

Also, one of the torches reveals hidden writing sometimes, when you have it currently selected in your inventory. This is necessary to progress, but the game didn't make it sufficiently obvious.

You've got a notebook in-game in which you can make black-and-white sketches. This is handy with color-based puzzles.

The physics glitches out sometimes so you end up vibrating in place, unable to move from your position until you jump away.

You can't rebind the movement keys. I use a non-US keyboard layout and normally use the ESDF keys for gaming, so this is pretty awkward.
38584408.developer_response: you can rebind your movement keys if you start the game with the -show-screen-selector launch property. You can not leave your torches behind as we place them in your inventory whenever you reload the game. Don't forget to use the in-game hint system if you get stuck! :)

38566228.review:
Fantastic experience. Felt at times like the creators of Myst let the creators of The Room make a Myst spinoff.

The puzzles here are a bit simpler than the Myst series. Some look complex on the outside, but ended up simple, classic puzzles you've likely seen elsewhere.

The back third or fourth of the game felt a little disconnected to me. There was one "puzzle" towards the end that felt so out of place that it lowered my view of the game a little…but overall it was a great experience.

The abilty to quickly render screenshots as sketches in your notebook was a great add for a game of this type (although I wish I had been able to draw on the sketches directly). 

Hoping for a sequel! It will be a day-one buy for me.

Mac Note: I had a little bit of trouble getting it to run due to some default graphical settings, but was able to fix it somewhat quickly. 

Edit: Added a couple thoughts after finishing the game.

37986368.review:
Un puzzle game proche de la perfection.

Bien sûr on ne sort pas "décoiffé" de ce jeu, mais il a su trouvé un subtil équilibre :

L'histoire est evidement portée sur le fantastique mais cohérente. Avec une découverte progressive et une vraie fin (hein, The Witness!!!!).

Les graphismes sont plutôt sobre, mais agréables à regarder. Un mélange de mystérieux et de réalisme bien trouvé. Les décors fourmillent de détails, on sent un vrai travail pour rendre cette île réaliste, possédant sa propre histoire.

Les énigmes oscillent entre observations, combinaisons d'objets et purs jeux de logiques. Les jeux sont naturellement intégrés au décors et sont toujours habillés d'objets qui racontent leurs préparations par le maître des lieux. Ca n'a l'air de rien mais c'est  le genre de détails qui favorisent l'immersion !

La musique a été à mon avis un peu négligée. On retrouve un copier/collé d'un Thalos Principle, des sons zen à base de percussions et sons organiques. C'est assez joli et réposant, mais oubliable, voire parfois énervant.

Comme c'est un puzzle game, il faut parler de la difficulté, qui est assez bien dosée, bien que les plus aguerris à ce genre de jeu vont sûrement les résoudre assez facilement. Ce qui m'a donné le plus de difficulté étant plutôt la découverte d'objets, il faut être observateur!

Cerise sur le gâteau, il tourne sans problèmes sur Linux (à part quelques lags inexpliqués de temps en temps).
Par contre j'ai dû fouiller le forum pour savoir comment passer en Azerty, les touches n'étant pas "remappable" sans activer une obscure option de démarre. Je ne sais pas si ce problème est propre à Linux?

Au final, un travail bien fait et beaucoup de plaisir.

37508754.review:
When I bought this game I expected a mildly entertaining imitation of Myst, full of questionable puzzles and unoptimized technical performance, like so many of it's indie cousins. Instead, what I got was a game so well made, it's actually a better Myst than Myst. 

Everything about the visuals, the music and the sounds scream Myst, but upgraded to modern standards. Quern uses the same structure: solved puzzles unlock new areas with even more puzzles. They are all logical and even the more difficult ones are never unfair in retrospect. 

The story is well told in a series of 'encounters' and letters you'll find along the way.

The game looks and runs great. The island environments look beautiful and are very detailed. I was surprised a game looking this good didn't have performance problems. Many Unity engine games suffer from horrible frame pacing (microstutter). Not this game.

I really can't think of anything negative to say. If you are a Myst fan, buy it. You won't be disappointed.

Эту игру подарил мне мой муж - настолько он в меня, блондинку, верит. И не прогадал. Игра была с удовольствием пройдена, хоть и не без оглушительного скрежета мозгов над некоторыми загадками - каждая головоломочная победа воспринималась с диким восторгом.

36590246.review:
Quern is, in essence, a spiritual successor to the Mysts and Rivens of olde. It is absolutely chockful of puzzles, interesting lore, and unique architecture. It will make you think, make you frustrated, and provide that wonderful elation when your brain finally comprehends the mechanics of a specific challenge. 

I was deeply impressed by the sheer density of the puzzles in this game; a few rooms alone contained as many puzzles as all of Obduction (a deep disappointment despite its unique aspects) and roughly 95% of my time in-game was spent solving puzzles or exploring the area. Only 5% was spent looking for the next puzzles and feeling stuck without something to work on. The only time I would encourage someone to look at a guide is if they cannot find what to do next at all...don't look at a guide to get through a tough puzzle!

I can't recommend this game enough for anyone who enjoyed Cyan's early games or loves puzzle/mechanical games in general. This is truly a hidden gem.

36543296.review: Один из немногих квестов, где я смог избежать соблазна подглянуть в прохождение, а причина тому проста - здесь очень логичные пазлы. Проходится на одном дыхании, очень приятная картинка (чем-то напоминает последний Myst), сюжет неплох, хотя концовка банальна. Единственное за что я могу пожурить эту игру это обилие задач с забегом с одного конца острова в другой, но слава Ктулху, что остров тут маленький.

36513240.review:
Great game! The puzzles are all very solid -- they strike the right balance of head-scratching and light bulbs going off. Nothing feels really unfair, and when you stumble upon the solution of a puzzle, youThe mythos of the world is simple but acceptable, and the plot is straightforward. The visuals are polished and intriguing, and the sound quality ranks a solid Servicable.

You will need a good memory; oftentimes, you're presented with a puzzle that you can't solve -- but given some gizmo that grants you access to a previous mystery, so backtrack often if you're stuck.

Full disclosure: I still have my copy of Myst on CD from back in the day, and love the genre, so I'm typically pretty hard on these styles of games. The inspiration from Myst in this game is clear as day, but the game feels like a love letter rather than a ripoff.

36512831.review:
Spectacular! This is what almost 25 years of improvements in computer gaming bring you if you enjoyed "Myst," and wanted more, but also something better. The game play is immersive and convincing, with no frustrating barriers that seem to arise for no reason or require that you retrace long pathways to solve. The puzzles are challenging, but their solutions are not only reasonable in terms of difficulty, they also make sense in the context of the story. There's nothing arbitrary or absurd about them. This is the game "Obduction" should have been.

Interestingly, the four young men who created this were all born around the same time that Myst came out. Make of that what you will, but I think it at least says something about the impact the Miller brothers' had on our world.

36507367.review:
I really enjoyed Quern, most of the puzzles were fun and rewarding when you 'get it', paricularly the last one.

Some were a little obtuse and for about 3-4 I had to cheat and look online for pointers as to what to do next.

The also developers wove a meaningful world around the puzzles which reveals itself slowly during the game.

I got the game during a sale so it was as cheap as chips, and definitely worth it.

36488976.review: Top Spiel! Genial um mit seinem besten Freud mehrere Abende Rätsel zu lösen :)

36481957.review: A modern day Myst, with some inventory puzzles. Graphics are nice, if somewhat poorly optimized. Puzzles are classic Myst affair for the most part, leaving it to the player to deduct and induce solutions; very satisfying. Story is somewhat thin, but true to form for the genre. I could hardly bear to put it down over the couple days it took me to finish, great game.

36480571.review: Если вы любите квесты и головоломки, то заходите: ваш череп раскрошится и вам, наверное, будет хорошо. Если нет, то разворачивайтесь и бегите отсюда, придерживая мозг, чтобы не вывалился.

36480398.review:
Quern - это то, что я ожидал от Obduction.
Разработчики взяли нереальную высоту! Quern заслуживает место на одной полочке с Myst'ом.
P.S. Жаль, что такие великолепные Инди проекты не придаются широкой огласке :(

36470670.review:
High amount of mechanical and deciphering puzzles with a fairly simple but well brought out story.

None of the puzzles are overly complicated or time consuming as some of those in Myst or Obduction. The balance is quite good here. The map is also quite compact and you can walk very quickly by holding the shift key, so no need to constantly walk back and forth for minutes on end. Compact doesn't mean less space for puzzles though. There's plenty of things to figure out. And I mean, really, a lot!

Graphics are very decent. They've put a lot of details in the puzzle items/mechanics themselfs but the landscape is somewhat on the rough side. But at the same time, it also had some surprisingly impressive moments.

Usable items are clearly visible and you can even use the alt key to highlight everything you can interact with. So no need to pixel-search for anything either. There's also a nice in-game notebook you can use to draw pictures of the things you're looking at. While technically, this is just a screenshot mechanic, they've added a nice touch to it by making it visually look like pencil drawings which is both cool and fitting in my opinion.

This was certainly a very enjoyable experience.

36464239.review:
En digne héritier de Myst, Quern nous propose une histoire et une narration similaire avec des énigmes dont la principale difficulté consistera à comprendre comment tout ceci fonctionne.

Une ambiance épurée, simple et parsemée de petits détails qui rendent le parcours de l'île plaisant. Les énigmes ne sont pas trop difficiles bien qu'à certains moment vous risquez de ne plus savoir où aller. Pas d'inquiétude, il est possible d'obtenir des indices sur les objets de l'inventaire et ça, c'est une très bonne idée qui ne gâche pas trop le plaisir de jeu.

Un bémol sur la deuxième phase de jeu qui devient linéaire. On aurait apprécié plus de liberté surtout face à un nouvel environnement.

Petite (grosse ?) faiblesse d'optimisation où l'afichage de la carte du jeu et les crédits de fin rament (baisse du framerate de moitié) !

En somme, Quern c'est comme un monde de Myst. C'est immersif et plaisant, au point que les défauts d'optimisation graphique se feront oublier (tant qu'on ne regarde pas la carte ^^). C'est un monde de Myst et c'est un peu dommage de n'avoir qu'un seul véritable environnement à parcourir et pas plus.

Ne boudez pas votre plaisir, fans de Myst, c'est du bon !

36455438.review: Great game! Challenging puzzles in an immersive world, reminiscent of the Myst adventures.

36450562.review:
A decent Myst-like.

[b]Puzzles - 9/10[/b]
Almost all the puzzles are excellent: well-thought out and exactly enough hints. I have to dock a few points for how tedious some of them are, even after you figured out how to solve them.

[b]Gameplay - 6/10[/b]
Nothing out of the ordinary, except for a button that highlights interactable objects. It's still a little subtle, I've spent about 5 occasions trying to find the missing puzzle pieces. Walking speed is a little fast, especially considering there's a button to run.

[b]Graphics - 7/10[/b]
The game is pretty, and there's a good amount of graphics settings (including head-bob and FoV, thank God). The visuals are pretty bland though, everything is brown and there's hardly any change of scenery.

[b]Sound - 6/10[/b]
The music is nice, but it changes per area, which can be annoying since you have to travel through some areas to get to others. One of the voice actors also isn't great.

[b]Overal - 7.5/10[/b]

36430311.review:
I'll start with the problems I experienced during my playthrough which as I'm writing this is probably about 80% of the way through.  
Performance:   The initial loading screen after selecting 'new game' had me thinking the game broke.  It took about a minute to load the last 20 seconds of which was a frozen screen.   This happened each time I loaded a save, but it would eventually load with no further signs of performance issues during gameplay.   
Puzzles:  Most were fairly straightforward and made sense, but there were  handful, probably 7 in total, where I lost patience, eventually cheated by watching a playthrough and either was angry with myself for overlooking something obvious or annoyed that my line of thinking did not match that of the developers.  For instance, and I will try to avoid spoilers by changing the details of the puzzle, I see a set two sets of symbols which I correctly identify belong to an object however, my thinking is I need to find pieces to place over lights to recreate the symbols to unlock a key.  That was not the case and I was supposed to look at the symbols and move the lights to match something in the symbols.  There were other puzzles that I unlocked unintentionally and unknowingly because I didn't realize it was a puzzle and was just touching buttons to see what they do and then didn't understand that I had already unlocked the puzzle.

So with the complaining done, I enjoyed the storyline and despite my above frustrations found myself continuing to play because I wanted to see how the backstory would conclude.   The music had a nice ambient feel that changed as you went through different areas.  The color scheme is kind of gray and bland.  I generally prefer vibrant colors in these types of games, but the textures were nice enough to overcome that.  Inventory is a bit wonky as I've seen stated in other reviews, but was certainly not game breaking.  So while it didn't match my ideal puzzle game standard, I would still consider it well made, well thought out, and worth buying.   I bought it on sale for $12.49 and thought that was a good price for it.

36425610.review: Holy shit!  Myst fans will like.

36405970.review: A great adventure game. No doubt it is a Riven clone - the island, the rotating chamber, even a sort of power domes, are there. Reasonable puzzles, well fitted into the context, and - unlike Obduction - they do not ask you to traverse endess distances to put things together. If something has to be done in a different location it is rationally inferable from the context. My only ciriticism is that there is no real story behind and the main purpose of the undoubtfully witty puzzles is to provide keys for opening doors. All in all a great performance by the young designer team which deserves our support for their future projects.

36401447.review:
The game is ok. The puzzles are balanced, not crazy nor too easy. With some time (eheheh) you can solve all the game without any help. I didn't even need the ingame hint system, but know that there is. Overall, a fair game.
The replayability is very low. Once you know the puzzles, there's no reason to play again, but you can play it once and enjoy your quest and the story.

36383614.review:
Merci. 
Merci pour ce magnifique jeu.
Pour son incroyable cohérence, pour la quasi perfection de sa construction.
Pour ses puzzles "juste comme il faut", récalcitrants parfois, infaisables jamais. Chaque réussite est un vrai plaisir d'enfant. Je ne comprends pas ceux qui ont "torché" le jeu en quelques heures. 36378667.review: I've never left a Steam review before, so I'm "breaking the seal" here, but this game is astonishingly good. The puzzles are often challenging but always fair, and you feel a great sense of accomplishment when you figure something out. Solving the puzzles is almost addictive - so many times you have no idea what you need to do or how to accomplish it at first, and then little by little everything just falls into place. The world is beautiful, immersive, haunting, and lonely, and the mystery of the world and constant sense of discovery keeps you wanting more. Outstanding work. Hope these guys keep making games.

36378235.review: Well-designed puzzles with a good story.

36376782.review: Just finished Quern, a massive game designed and produced by a bunch of young 20-somethings in Hungary.  The game is at least twice the visual richness and complexity of Obduction.  I highly recommend this game to all who are fans of  Myst, Riven and Exile.  At times you will be hair-pullingly frustrated by some of the puzzles but you will never be disappointed.  I really  look forward to their next game especially because games of this calibur are so far and few between.

36367848.review:
Quern is a super enjoyable puzzle game that I'm surprised I hadn't heard of before I played it. It has a lot in common with the Myst series (including some definite nods to the franchise), but it's still it's own game. It's like if the original Myst was turned into an adventure game with an inventory. A lot of the puzzles are very self contained--as compared to something like Riven where understanding the world is the puzzle--but there are points where you need to go back and re-use tools from before but in a different way with your new knowledge. Frequently, you'll find yourself approaching some complicated machine and needing to both figure out how it works and subsequently what you need to make it do, which will be familiar for anyone who's played Myst. My one general criticism of the puzzles is that it felt like too many of them revolved around just finding a solution written nearby and spending a little time interpreting it. 

Overall, it's a wonderful game with a cool world and lots of cool puzzles, and I would definitely recommend it to anyone who enjoyed Myst, The Witness, or any sort of adventure/puzzle game.

36365590.review: With this game, I played a new Myst-like experience with better graphics, and for that I am trully thankful.

36353609.review:
Ein würdiger Nachfolger der Myst-Tradition. Die Rätsel in Quern sind immer logisch und nachvollziehbar. Auch an der Vielfalt der Rätsel lässt das Spiel nichts zu wünschen übrig. Der Soundtrack, die Grafik und der unglaubliche Detailreichtum bereichern das spannende Spielprinzip, ohne vom Inhalt abzulenken. Die Story ist interessant, wenn man etwas Fantasie mitbringt. 
Als jemand der an den undurchsichtigen Rätselstrukturen von RIven fast eingegangen ist, möchte ich besonders den gelungenen Spielfluss loben. Erfolge bzw. Fehler werden schnell und eindeutig reflektiert, die Umgebung gibt immer klare, eindeutige Hinweise und die Lernkurve steugt während des Verlaufs stetig an. 
Alles in allem kann ich diesen Titel nur jedem empfehlen, der bereits mit den Myst-Teilen aufgewachsen ist oder einfach Rätsel jeder Form liebt.

36332025.review:
This game is indeed very much like the Myst series, and as such, shares its good and bad aspects.

Pro:

- Graphics are excellent.
- Puzzles are varied, challenging, and interesting.
- In the item window, there is some optional help to suggest what the item is for (for those of us with limited imagination).
- There is an option to highlight usable objects, even when the focus is not on them.
- There is a map (although it's not used in the last part of the game).

Con (hardware usage):

- For a game with very little real-time action (some would say none), it needs surprisingly heavy resources. On my system (i5-3330 + GTX 950 + 12GB RAM), at 1600x900 resolution, I got a decent 50 fps, but the 4-core CPU was at 85%, and the GPU ran at 80C. Even at that, there were often gaps when panning/moving. Changing the graphics quality from Ultra all the way down to Low seemed to have little effect, if any.

- The game checks your hardware on install, and sets the graphics options to what it thinks is best. Unfortunately, once you change them from that, there's no easy way to get those initial settings back. In light of the point above though, this may be irrelevant.

- Controller support is not complete enough (yet) to be used alone - you still need the mouse and keyboard for some things. In the end, I found the best experience was in Mouse + Keyboard mode (only) configuring my Steam controller to mimic the native controller layout (with a few personalizations).

Con (the game itself):

- Like Myst, the story doesn't make much sense until near the end, and even then it's not very deep.

- Again like Myst, it is often very hard to know where to go next, or what to do when you get there. There are clues, but they are often subtle and easy to miss. Many of the clues are relevant to other locations, so unless you have a near-photographic memory, you spend a lot of time re-checking everywhere you've been to see what clue you might have missed. At first, I had to rely heavily on a walk-through. As things progressed, I got better at knowing what to look for and remember, and how to interpret it, so I needed the walkthrough less and less, but I was never able to do without it completely. Let's have a round of applause for those good folks who devote the many hours of time and effort it takes to create those walkthroughs!

- Even a walkthrough can't help with some of the hard puzzles that use random combinations that reset when you fail. One of these requires you to memorize and reproduce a 14-long random light/tone sequence that you see and hear only once. If you find that you can't do that, you have absolutely no way to continue the game.


The bottom line:

In spite of my negative comments, I still enjoyed it. If you liked the Myst series, you'll almost certainly like this game too.

36311014.review:
Summary: Worth a purchase when on sale.

Quern takes the best of the Myst gameplay and improves upon it. The graphics and audio narration is refined. The setting is lovely. The puzzles are challenging. In fact, the puzzles are so varied you will undoubtedly need to reference external material (guides and spoilers) to pass some of the more challenging puzzles. But, Quern goes one step further than Myst ever did, introducing some puzzles that are randomized.

The most frustrating of these was a 12 step simon says. By itself, it was challenging but not overly so. Add in a pencil that kept breaking 6 times and a written mistake for the 7th time (using a pen)-- you (like I) may find yourself incredibly frustrated. Still others require a lot of thought and attention to detail.

Quern also features a save system-- although my experience was that it saved back to a recent save point in the story rather than to exactly where you saved it.

Overall, I was pleased with Quern. I recommend it. I got it on sale and thought it was a bargain. If puzzles aren't your thing, don't get it. If you might be frustrated by the RNG and overly complex puzzles, then buy it only on sale. At full price, it's a bit pricey for the amount of playtime you're going to get. So I do not recommend it at full price.

A fantastic puzzle-adventure game that manages to avoid the common pitfall of "What the hell was the Dev thinking when he made this puzzle?". 

Every puzzle in the game can be solved with logical thinking and examining notes and context clues around the island. There were very few instances where I had to look up where to go next and each time it was only because I had missed something obvious.

36251154.review: Bellissimo! Miglior gioco rompicapo che abbia mai giocato.

36250808.review: Quern - Undying Thoughts is beautiful.  It is a Sisyphean task to create a puzzle game that will appeal to all since the challenges must be surmountable but involve enough thought so as not to roll down into a clicker game.  I personally like to have my grey matter stretched but I do not enjoy having to combine calculus with chess and hope that I noticed a word on a wall discoverable only within the first 2 minutes of gameplay.  I will say the puzzles were tilted towards the mechanical side of the equation as opposed to the theoretical, which is true to the story as they have been physically created as both tests and a guide.  The puzzle progress is linear, but this remains true to the theme of the story.  I did hit the forums near the beginning of the adventure at one point where I could not determine where there even was a path to follow, but in retrospect, there were clues.  This keyed me into noting what might guide me later.  If you are looking for the New York Times Sunday Diagramless, the puzzles might seem dissapointly easy.  However, I enjoy feeling the satisfaction of solving challenges on my own rather than just clicking along to a walk through so I found them well ballanced.  If you want a gorgeous environment with enjoyable puzzling all wrapped up in a capable story line, Quern is a gem.

36194756.review:
На днях поиграл в данную игру и вот что я вам скажу. Эта игра превосходна! Потрясающа! Я уже несколько лет не играл в такой красивый, а вместе с тем и логичный своими загадками, квест. Игра во всём прекрасна: это и трудные, и в то же время решаемые, загадки; и не плохая графическая реализация; и атмосферный, глубокий, трогающий глубину души саундтрек. 36182520.review: A solid Myst clone, although the story doesn't compare.  Like Myst, here you wander around an alien environment and figure out how to make things work. The puzzles are very challenging, and it's quite segmented by "area"--you can't progress to the next area until you finish the one you're in, and so on.  I tend to prefer more "open world" concepts, where you can work on numerous puzzles simultaneously (taking a break from one when you get stuck to go work on something else). That way, you don't have to completely stop when you get stuck. This one was very chronological, and the "choice" at the end wasn't nearly as witty or interesting as Myst. Mostly, the "letters" you encounter along the way were redundant. It would have been nice to have a more likeable character to follow. All this being said, if you need a "Myst" fix, this is a great choice. The puzzles were mostly solveable without help (although I did need a hint or two here and there), and the mechanics were intuitive (which is to say, there were enough hints that you could figure stuff out.  Nothing more frustrating, say, than a door with a code and no hints whatsoever about how to find the correct code. Trying thousands of combinations is not a fun way to waste hours of your life). Overall, I enjoyed playing this, and thought it was well worth the $12 I spent on it.

36176930.review:
Absolutely marvelous, really can't praise it enough. 

It's not the world's longest game, but for something of this genre it may well be the perfect length. Long enough for you to get into the swing of things and sink into its world, but short enough that it doesn't start to drag.

A few puzzles early on drove me to look things up, but I quickly realised that the game was just asking for more detail then I expected and after adapting accordingly it hit a pretty steady beat of problem-confusion-eureka-solution. Obviously not going to spoil but the very last puzzle especially was perfect. 

After playing through it in a single day I consider it to have been a wonderful way to spend a holiday, an experience that has left me feeling thoroughly sated. I can only hope that the devs will release more games like this. I'm not sure sequels would make sense but if they're willing to devise more worlds in this setting or in entirely new ones...well I'll damn sure buy the games.

36165250.review:
This is a beautifully made puzzle game in the Myst tradition. If you enjoyed the serenity of being on your own on an island in Myst, you'll love Quern - Undying Thoughts. It actually seems to pay a number of hommages to Myst with its visuals and puzzles that often are represented as mechanical devices.  

The graphics are great (not perfect, but easily good enough for a very immersive experience). The soundtrack is very atmospheric as well. I really appreciated the automatically expanding map and the notebook which allows one to not only capture snapshots (sketches) but also to write one's own notes so that one can browse through them later to see whether a new found object can be used in a previously visited location, for instance. 

I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys exploring abandoned worlds and have only a few suggestions for improvement: I found some of the puzzles rather easy as such, but very obscure to approach. In other words, it was not obvious a couple of time what to do next and there were far too many options to make a trial and error approach to exploration satisfying. In hindsight, every step is logical, but as a matter of fact, other steps would have been logical as well and I don't enjoy trying all those options. Most of the time, one receives enough hints (through notes and drawings left behind, or through properties of objects) that one has a motivation to find another item or attempt a task, but a few times I found there were gaps in driving the next move. Sometimes the search space was confined enough to make educated exploration feasible, but sometimes it was just too vast for my taste.  

I would also have loved to see more organic puzzles. Some of the puzzles in the game are of this type, i.e., you are just trying to create or fix something that someone else would have done as well, if they just lived in that place. But many puzzles involved elaborate machinery that had not other purpose than to present a puzzle to you. Why not, say, fix an elevator that looks like people would use, rather than operate a contraption that purely appears to be an obstacle made for you as a puzzler? The narrative of the game justifies pure puzzles in your path, but still, solving those hurdles does not feel as satisfying to me, compared to accomplishing tasks that actually make sense outside a pure puzzle challenge. 

A bit more story along the way would also have been appreciated. This would have added to the urgency, the desire to see what's next. As it is, one basically already knows the path from day one and there are no major reveals on the way. At one point a bit of interest is added but that then remains static as well till the end. So for the vast majority of the time one just wonders what the next puzzle will look like. 

In conclusion, my criticism is a bit of nitpicking at an extremely high level. I thoroughly enjoyed this game and couldn't recommend it any more to the republic of puzzlers. :)

36155143.review:
Really good game. The world is beautiful, the puzzles can be extremely challenging but are reasonable for the most part, and the plot is half decent. You will definitely get frustrated playing this game, and unless you have an incredible amount of patience you may not be able to complete the game without taking a peek here and there at a forum or a walkthrough. I had to cheat 3 or 4 times, but given the vast amount of challenges in this game, it did not greatly deter from the experience. 

I highly recommend this title! A standout in the genre. I'd put it at better than Obduction, not as good as Talos Principle.

36153119.review: Now this is the game worthy of the mantle of the successor to Myst/Riven. Fantastic puzzles and world, good music, and nice atmosphere. I played Obduction to completion and while it was a good (and very welcome, desperately needed entry into the genre) it just didn't quite feel "Myst-y" like Quern does. Quern actually feels like a new entry into the Myst games and it does it very well. The puzzles are challenging, yet logical, and the story and world is all there for you explore. My only (extremely minor) gripe is the world has a bit of a dull color palette at times and performance can be spotty. But otherwise this is a sublime adventure puzzle game and I hope Zadbox makes more games like this.

36151666.review: Уже давно придерживаюсь мнения, что игра - это прекрасный контейнер для контента. Она позволяет более глубже понять сюжет игры. Пусть в данном случае он не слишком замысловат, но упакован очень красиво, компактно и логично. Без сомнений Quern - одна из лучших игр-головоломок. 10/10

36141218.review:
My initial impressions? This is what Obduction should have been, what it deserved to be. In tone, in atmosphere, in eccentricity, and the sheer ingenuity shown in so much of the puzzle and environment design. Quern delivers what I actually wanted from Obduction that that game never delivered.

It's a fair comparison because it's the most direct one out there right now vis-a-vis recently released Myst-like games. And honestly, this is truly the best sample of the genre I've had the delight of enjoying so much in quite, quite some time.

36135698.review: Great game. Challenging but not unsolvable puzzles and a nice atmospheric level design.

36128713.review:
A worthy successor to the Myst series. Beautiful graphics, decent puzzles to solve, and enough story to back it all up. For all the Myst games, I'd wind up filling one A4 page with notes (taking up more space as the series progressed). Quern had me taking almost two pages of notes, and spent more time exploring and testing answers than I had with any other game. 

The story doesn't keep much back. There are fewer questions left unanswered or implied by the game's conclusion, but still a nifty tale to run through. Would totally pre-purchase a sequel if it ever comes out. I've spent Ages waiting for a game like this to come out again.

Great game. Reminds me of The Talos Principle. The parts that took me the longest to figure out are those where you need to discover a clue, how some in-game mechanic works or to find that tiny note where the clue to the påassword is written.

All in all it took me 17 hours to play through the game with both endings and I didnt feel I was stuck for too long at any time.

36094783.review:
[h1]Summary[/h1]
[b][i]Quern - Undying Thoughts[/i][/b] is a wonderful puzzle adventure game with a beautifully constructed world and narrative. Many will immediately describe it as a [b][i]Myst[/i][/b]-like game, however, I found it much closer in mechanics to [b][i]The Room[/i][/b] series. The game's puzzles are much less obscure than [b][i]Myst[/i][/b], however, it is closer to the [b][i]Myst[/i][/b] series in the adventure and story aspect compared to [b][i]The Room[/i][/b] series. If you enjoy puzzle and adventure games, [b][i]Quern - Undying Thoughts[/i][/b] should not disappoint.

[h1]Audio[/h1]
The audio was one of my favorite parts of this game. The sound track is superbly done and was perfectly crafted for the areas you will experience during the game. I personally wouldn't spend more money to purchase the sound track separately, but that is not an indication the sound track isn't worth while. I simply feel it was well crafted to the experiences of the game and I don't think I would listen to it separately.

The Voicing for the game was also very well done. The voice actors did a great job in delivering the emotion in their lines which fit the story perfectly. The recording engineer also did a fantastic job capturing the performances which resulted in some of the best narrative quality I've heard in this genre. All in all the voicing is just as superb as the sound track and both serve to draw you into the game's world very effectively.

[h1]Visual[/h1]
[b][i]Quern - Undying Thoughts[/i][/b] will initially feel very drab in it's visuals. As you make your way around the initial square you will undoubtedly get a sense that there is more wonder just beneath the surface of the dull stone facade. As you progress  through the story you will find increasing beauty and complexity in the areas and puzzles that unfold at a pace that is in lock-step with the narrative.

The graphics are not amazing or photo-realistic, however, they are well done and look great. There are plenty of scenery objects that clip into each other as a simple means to fill areas with some detail without spending a lot of time on things that aren't a focus area. I thought this was well balanced and it shows with the additional details put into the objects that are interactive. The world seems to have been meticulously built around the narrative and the design team built some interesting and beautiful spaces that really help immerse you in the game and it's puzzles.

[h1]Puzzles[/h1]
The complexity and difficulty of the puzzles have a fairly liner progression that adherers to the lore put forth by the story. The problems presented vary in type and function, some of which build upon each other. This reminded me of how [b][i]The Witness[/i][/b] built up several core mechanics and rules that then combined and stacked upon one another, however, [b][i]Quern - Undying Thoughts[/i][/b] does not do this at the same scale. With [b][i]Quern - Undying Thoughts[/i][/b] this feels much more like a progression of a mechanic along a story arc and much less like it is a combination of rules for the sole purpose to increase complexity of the puzzle as it was with  [b][i]The Witness[/i][/b].

The difficulty of the puzzles I felt was less than any of the [b][i]Myst[/i][/b] series due to the puzzles being less abstract, however, that is not to say there isn't a challenge. Nor does this mean solving them is any less satisfying. In fact I felt the progression and more linear arrangement of the puzzles immersed me further into the storyline. The larger "milestone" puzzles have several smaller roadblocks that keep you feeling like you are progressing with little victories as you solve the larger puzzle to progress the story and unlock new things. The pacing will obviously vary depending on you as an individual, however, I felt this was one of the strongest points of the game. There wasn't any point that I felt I wasn't able to progress because I might have missed something earlier. They did a good job making you feel like everything you need to solve a puzzle is available to you.

[h1]Adventure[/h1]
The story is well thought out and is similar in concept to that of [b][i]The Room[/i][/b]. The lore is interesting and the narrative feeds this to the player in a fitting mechanic that is rewarding as you progress through the puzzles. It wasn't shocking or all that unpredictable, however, it was very enjoyable. Once you get about 3/4 of the way though its not hard to predict the general concept of the end, however, the details of how that plays out are fun and interesting. There are even a couple nods to a couple of my favorite adventure books/movies which I won't name to prevent spoiling things for you.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Fairly linear progression to puzzle difficulty and complexity
    [*]Good challenge while trying not to leverage obscurity as a difficulty mechanic
    [*]Very well balanced mix of problem solving and story telling
    [*]Very good audio & visual use to set a compelling mood to envelope the player within the game's lore
    [*]Good sound track that may be worth picking up if you enjoy listening to VGM outside of games
    [*]Great voice acting, sound engineering, and sound design
    [*]Very polished, I didn't experience any glitches or bugs
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Has a couple plot holes that defy logic, however, I didn't find this took away from the game significantly
    [*]Some people have reported issues running the game with minimum specs, however, this shouldn't be much of an issue as the recommended specs are fairly entry level for a gaming PC
    [*]The developers missed some opportunities for potentially interesting puzzles or branches in the storyline
[/list]

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
I'd highly recommend [b][i]Quern - Undying Thoughts[/i][/b] to any one who is interested in puzzle or adventure games. Its well worth the price and should provide you with around 10 - 30 hours of a fun and enjoyable story. This game nails the high notes of adventure that made the [b][i]Myst[/i][/b] franchise so great. It could have been a little more challenging, however, the developers did a wonderful job balancing difficulty with the progression of the story. Great game, go ahead and click the Buy button already so you can be whisked away to the beautiful world of [b][i]Quern - Undying Thoughts[/i][/b]

36092721.review:
Quern is a puzzle game which takes place on a island with puzzles based around language, number, herbology, element and machines, This is a really good vertical slice of what a modern first person puzzle game is. Nothing is too hard, I got lost not knowing what to do next a couple of times, but that is all part of the fun of the hunt and exploration. What starts out a mysterious and unknown becomes familiar and puzzles which start out perplexing will become mastered by the end of the adventure. Like a lot of games the player is presented with a choice at the end and it is very arbitrary as to which yo choose, which is a shame, but Quern's story is interesting for the most part.

Graphically it is a very nice looking game with the exception of a few textures here and there. The soundtrack is quite muted, which is a shame because there are some good tracks. My biggest gripe with the music is that it doesn't reflect the environment very much and when you move between areas the soundtrack doesn't blend like it should do in this kind of game.

If you are a fan of first person puzzle games, or even puzzle games in general, I can highly recommend Quern.
4/5

A must-have for any puzzle game fan. Comparing it to Myst doesn't quite give it enough credit for what it accomplishes on its own, but thematically parallels are there. Still, it goes far beyond point-and-click gameplay, and the world you discover piece-by-piece unfolds spectacularly from the second you start playing until you enter the final sections of the game, all accompanied by a gripping story and a beautiful soundtrack.

Some puzzles feel like a leap of logic is required (I'll admit I'm not above using guides when I get stuck, which happened quite a bit), and others just felt tedious, but they're an extreme minority compared to everything else this game has to offer.

36003627.review:
The original Myst series is quite sacred to me. Any game claiming to be inspired by it is going to be held to a very high standard. This title meets that standard and beyond...it is an impressive, artful, and well executed piece, and it brings me great satisfaction and enjoyment. The puzzle difficulty is just perfect, and the puzzles are intertwined beautifully. Each breakthrough brings a bit of excitement, as new areas and possibilities unfold, revealing new mysteries and challenges.

This work is everything Myst could have been, had the technology existed in its time. The setting, themes and story line are original, though clearly inspired by Myst, but you do not have to be a Myst fan to appreciate the quality.

The developers paid very close attention to little details, and it makes such a difference. The voice acting, lore items, maps and story art are sumptuous, and they have innovated a great new notebook feature that allows you to sketch a screenshot. It is the first time I have seen it in an adventure game, and it's a beautiful idea.

Speaking as a Myst fan myself, I was thrilled to discover this title. It is indeed a childhood wish come true!

It's amazing all of the puzzles and re-used elements packed into a tightly condenced area.  The puzzles were creative with sufficient clues.  The UI was very well done.  My only disappointment, was when we solved the final puzzle and the game was over.  Looking forward to the next one!

35979633.review:
Recommended WITH CAVEATS... (more like yes and no)

Is it as good as very good? No

The game is a little rough around the edges, but works well enough to enjoy.

Linux performance is not good. With my humble GPU and a 6 core CPU everything has to be put to low or off in the quality settings. If you have Windows, there's only one real choice: Don't play in linux!

Windows performance is approx 75% better and can get in between med and high quality with the same hardware.

But performance in general is just horrible compared to AAA titles with far greater draw distance and detail. Edit: With linux this is how I feel. In Windows with the higher quality settings the game looks better than it did at first. It has grown on me and I kind of like the way it looks now. There are some well done parts later on and some glitchy parts as well.

Anti-aliasing is horrible here. Enabling it removed jagged edges but makes objects highly blurry. Tree detail becomes that of the blind.

The story is interesting (maybe 1-2 minutes of story in about 2 hours). Is it done in a way that is anywhere near that of Myst? Not even close. Later on the story gains more ground and I found myself quite bored during it because of the way its done - a rather import part and long part of the story was done in a really boring way.

There's jump ability but plenty of invisible walls. You can't fall off of anything despite having jump ability and so far it feels like they just left it in instead of removing the ability. It has so far only helped to get out of a boat without trying to walk in a different angle. After 20 hours I've seen no real need for jumping excet to get out of glitchy spots where the player gets stuck.

I do like the fact that you can view letters and close them while the voiceover continues.

Arrow keys are default bound

Its rather bland looking. Edit: It improves later on after some areas are unlocked and further from there. There are some really nice looking places and its not all rock and overcast sky.

What about the puzzles? You start off right away with one. Every door seems to be locked! So you're solving puzzles opening doors to new areas. They are varied and kind of interesting. Some are more like adventure games where you put an object into the holder or whatever and that's the puzzle finding where it goes. Then there's sliding blocks around to get the blocks in a certain place or directing light. And more.

Some puzzles are really annoying. Some are fun. Some puzzles are redone. Some puzzles will make you confused. Some will not be what you wanted but its what you get.

There's one puzzle where you literally need to use the zoom click of the middle mouse button to read the symbols well. Not terriblly fond of that, but its functional. I'm sure someone will liken it to a magnifying glass in the real world but whatever.

The inventory ... edits.... Sometime after 2 hours I realized that the scroll wheel allows srolling through a use inventory. So that the object chosen is the one that is used in the world. This is necessary at times when there's multiple objects in the inventory as sometimes multiple objects can be used with the same use point.

The game can't be completed without using the inventory in everway possible.

Edits... After 20 hours (took 23 hours for me to complete) and seeing how the game changes, being longer than I expected (so many puzzles everywhere, more and more) and the better performance and quality provided by Windows, I still recommend this game and at 20 hours have not completed it yet (and I feel I'm solving every puzzle at a good pace).

It could be better, it could be worse. Its not Myst but its along that line. Myst has a better told storyline - though its interesting - and it takes some time to like the game more as the first bunch of hours are somewhat lacking but the game has some great moments. After completion, I feel that it has some moments that may even be better than Myst.

Some people may get fed up with some of the puzzles. They even have a puzzle where you need to know something about chess which I found to be rather off and another one that seems out of place. And some parts are annoying because you have a difficult time seeing. So these are some points where it could be better. There's more, but they can be overlooked and dealt with (just annoyances perhaps).

35558982.review:
it took me a while to finish the game, but it was worth it, the game has challenging puzzles, some of which have a fairly obvious solution or procedure to solve them, others are a bit more hit and miss with some guesswork as they can be vague.
the narrative isn't bad and while the voiceovers are good, you either like or dislike the voices.
I also have seen both endings after which i can conclude that while i must say that i prefer the followers ending the other ending is just as good and leaves little to wish for but maybe a second game.


as for the negatives i have to add that the game is quite the GPU resource hog and may or may not crash and or freeze because of this, but overall thats about the most negative i could find about it. and since i am playing on a linux it may work better on windows (or worse) but is very stable in general.
the second negative is that while the story is fine it does feel awkward at times, and hints as to where you are supposed to go next or clues as to what step you are missing, can be non existant, then again, its a puzzle game, find your own answers and questions.

another good thing, or bad... is that only has 1 (!) loading screen, which is the divider between the 2 halves of the game (over and underworld). while it is enough to have split the resources in two, at times i do get the feeling theres a bit to much going on in the background in either of the 2 halves of the game which results in framedrops and the game getting a bit slower, thats the drawback of having a big busy world in unity i suppose.
i ran the game on a gtx 1080, 32GB ram and a i5-7600K, all settings turned to their highest quality, lowering this will help if needed.


my final verdict is simply, if you like puzzle games and something relaxing, then i definatly can recommend this game.

35425233.review: A really excellent Myst-like with wonderful visuals and an enchanting soundtrack. WARNING: You have to be able to hear to solve at least one of the puzzles. I would rate this as better than Obduction, which was a little clunky in places. Took me around 30 hours to finish but I absolutely agonized over a couple of the puzzles. Small amounts of jank when you are required to rotate things in the game world, but you can work past it. Very satisfying experience!

35362191.review:
Best myst-like I've played. Music is great, the puzzles are great, and the clever use of context clues help reduce the worst of puzzle games when you have no idea how to progress for an extended length of time. This happened to me twice, and to give anyone who tries this a tip make sure to check your items (and letters) in your inventory when you get them. It also helps to play the whole thing in a week- I took an extended break and forgot an important detail for later.
The only negative I have are some artifacts of the translation, like some run-on sentences and weird constructions. Still, it's great to have most of the text narrated. The game is also quite a good looker and I had no performance issues. The only noticeable graphical issue was some pop-in from distant islands. This game deserves much more attention and I look forward to any future puzzle games from Zadbox.

35334288.review: I liked the soundtrack of the trailer and so decided to give this game a shot and I was not disappointed at all. Very well done game and not very easy puzzles requiring deep thinking. If you are a stubborn like me in solving every puzzle with no hint then this game will take time.

Grafica spettacolare, musica coinvolgente, storia strana (a volte un po banale) e finale a sorpresa. Rompicapi molto divertenti (spesso complicatissimi).
